metadata./Title: Effective blind bilateral superficial cervical plexus block for tracheostomy tube insertion in a geriatric patient with Ludwig angina with hypertension in resource constrained area: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Introduction:
Introduction Ludwig angina is a rare, rapidly spreading submaxillary, submandibular, and sublingual necrotizing 
life-threatening widespread cellulitis of the soft tissue on the floor of the mouth that can cause fatal complications 
because of airway obstruction. Currently, there are few published studies assessing the efficacy of superficial cervical 
plexus block for airway surgery and there is no agreement in the literature about airway management. The published 
recommendations differ and are based on the authors’ own experiences and available resources. This report aimed 
to provide insight into critical patient management by performing regional anesthesia with fewer complications 
to the cardiovascular and respiratory systems.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation We report the case of a 70 year-old hypertensive Black Ethiopian woman with American Society 
of Anesthesiologist–Physical Status class III and hypertension, who was admitted to the hospital for treatment by her 
surgeon. The surgeon diagnosed her with Ludwig angina. After adequate physical examination and laboratory investigation, she arrived at the operation room for exploration and drainage of the abscess with a superficial cervical plexus 
block. She arrived safely at the adult intensive care unit for frequent suctioning. The block was effective until 6 h 
after the procedure with visual analogue scale (2/10), her vital signs remained stable throughout the postoperative 
period, and then the tracheostomy tube was removed by the surgeon after 10 days. The patient’s hemodynamic 
status and breathing effort were satisfactory, and she was discharged 15 days later.
Clinical
sections.Discussion:
discussion Proper airway management is critical for the survival of patients diagnosed with Ludwig angina. 
According to recent studies, an increasing number of patients with Ludwig angina require intensive care unit admission for tracheal intubation and mechanical breathing. However, it is uncertain whether intensive care reduces 
the death rate in patients with Ludwig angina. Finally, it is suggested that studies with large sample sizes and strong 
levels of evidence be conducted to conclude the effectiveness of superficial cervical plexus block for airway emer gency surgeries.Open Access

Introduction
Ludwig angina is a rare, rapidly spreading, submaxillary, 
submandibular, and sublingual necrotizing life-threaten ing widespread cellulitis of the soft tissue on the floor of 
the mouth and neck that can cause fatal complications 
because of airway obstruction. This is uncommon in cur rent practice [1]. Ludwig angina is less frequently associ ated with a variety of aerobic and anaerobic bacteria, as 
well as fungi, including oral flora such as streptococci and 
staphylococci [2, 3]. Ludwig angina has several etiolo gies and risk factors. Odontogenic infection causes 70% 
of Ludwig angina cases [4]. Affected patients are typically 
between the ages of 20 and 60  years, with a high male 
predominance [5]. Currently, few published studies have 
assessed the efficacy of superficial cervical plexus block 
for airway surgery and there is no agreement in the lit erature about airway management. The published rec ommendations differ and are based on the authors’ own 
experiences and available resources [6, 7]. This report 
aimed to provide insight into critical patient management 
by performing regional anesthesia with fewer complica tions to the cardiovascular and respiratory systems. This 
report is in line with the Case report (CARE) guidelines.Case presentation
We report the case of a 70  year-old hypertensive Black 
Ethiopian woman with American Society of Anesthesi ologist–Physical Status class III who was admitted to the 
hospital after she was diagnosed with Ludwig angina sec ondary to periodontal abscesses involving teeth numbers 
20 and 30. Despite receiving antibiotics, the patient expe rienced difficulty swallowing and breathing. She suddenly 
began desaturating (88–90% of the oxygen saturation) 
upon spontaneous breathing. She had tachycardia (heart 
rate of 110 beats per minute) and drowsiness.
She had a familial history of hypertension but no his tory of psychosocial-related admission to the hospi tal; she had good socioeconomic status and no familial 
history of chronic illnesses, such as diabetes mellitus, 
asthma, or other genetically related illnesses.
During admission, the patient was hypertensive, with 
a baseline blood pressure of 144/85  mmHg, shortness 
of breath, and hypoxia (Fig.  1). She was also taking anti hypertensive agent nifedipine (10 mg three times a day) 
and the beta blocker propranolol (20  mg twice a day) 
for 1  year. Her laboratory parameters, such as a hemo globin level of 14.2 g/dl and a white blood cell count of
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Management of the airway in patients with Ludwig angina is challenging. Clinicians must take precautions and make sharp decisions on the basis of a variety of circumstances, including the availability of equipment 
at medical facilities, such as fiberoptic intubation equipment; the anesthetist’s level of experience, such as performing 
superficial regional block and good mask ventilation; and the patient’s medical status at the time of presentation. As 
a result, intervention needs to be quick so as to avoid airway obstruction and further complications.

ultrasound scan because of the abscess, neck ultrasound 
was performed and revealed an extensive abscess with an 
estimated volume of 80 ml.
The medical team aggressively resuscitated her and 
brought her to the operating room for neck exploration 
(abscess drainage) and tracheostomy. During arrival to 
operation room, her oxygen saturation was 94–95% on 
portable nasal oxygen. We performed airway and sys temwise physical examinations. Unfortunately, it was 
difficult to open her mouth to determine the Mallampati 
score, thyromental distance, and sternomental distance. 
On chest auscultation, she had diminished air entry 
through both lungs, but systolic and diastolic sounds 
were well heard. Subsequently, there was good commu nication regarding the risks and benefits of performing 
blind bilateral superficial cervical plexus block versus 
ketamine-based sedation with patients and families with out language barriers or cultural or financial challenges. 
Informed written consent was obtained from the patient 
for using medical information and image for publication. 
We applied electrocardiography, pulse oximetry, non invasive blood pressure, and pericardial stethoscopy for 
the intraoperative monitoring of oxygenation and perfu sion. We maintained the patient with 500  ml of normal 
saline and 500  ml of 10% dextrose because the patient 
was abstained from oral intake and she had symptoms of 
hypoglycemia secondary to prolonged Nil per os (NPO) 
hour, and then we premedicated the patient with 10 mg 
of metoclopramide and 4 mg of dexamethasone. In addi tion we administered 80 mg of 2% plain lidocaine to blunt 
the patient’s airway from gag reflex during tracheostomy 
tube insertion.We applied an antiseptic solution of iodine and alco hol for skin preparation and then maintained adequate 
positioning by turning the head away and resting it on 
the surface. A small dose of fentanyl (25 µg) was admin istered to avoid late respiratory depression secondary to 
the high dose and injection pain. Then, we used the land mark technique and injected 10  ml on each side of the 
anteromedial block, targeting the midpoint of the sterno cleidomastoid muscle. We then observed the complica tions and onset of the block. The patient had a universal 
visual analogue score of 1/10 for a clamp pinch. She did 
not complain of any complications and she had stable 
vital signs intraoperativly (Fig. 2).
The exploration was initiated and suggested significant 
acute necrotizing inflammation of the deep soft tissues 
and the anterolateral compartment of the neck. After 
adequate exploration and drainage of the abscess, irriga tion was performed with hydrogen peroxide and normal 
saline.
Nonetheless, Ludwig angina is a progressive form of 
cellulitis that often

secondary to airway obstruction. Subsequent deep neck 
infections can complicate Ludwig angina. We examined 
the underlying etiologies and common scenarios and 
addressed and discussed the significant autopsy findings 
of Ludwig angina with several case reports.
Postoperative outcome and follow up
The team admitted her to the intensive care unit for fre quent suctioning. The block was effective for 6  h after 
the procedure with visual analogue scale (2/10) and her 
vital signs remained stable throughout the postopera tive period, and the surgeon removed the tracheostomy 
tube 10 days after, ensuring a satisfactory hemodynamic

status of oxygen saturation and blood pressure of 96% of 
oxygen saturation and 124/74  mmHg, respectively, with 
spontaneous breathing. The team investigated her with 
complete blood count (CBC) and found a white blood 
cell count of 6.4 ×  109/L, and also conducted a free neck 
examination with ultrasound. After 15 days, she was dis charged from the hospital.
Clinical discussion
For anesthetists and surgeons, managing patients with 
Ludwig angina is extremely difficult because of difficult 
airways, surgical manipulation of airways, and aspiration 
risk. A lack of proper oral health care predisposes preg nant women to odontogenic infections, which can lead 
to severe complications. Individuals who sometimes have 
chronic disease, who are geriatric or pregnant, or who do 
not receive adequate dental healthcare are more likely 
to have odontogenic infections, which can cause serious 
consequences.
Proper airway management is critical for the survival 
of patients diagnosed with Ludwig angina. The anesthe siologist’s experience and patient’s condition determine 
whether a conservative or aggressive strategy for airway 
preservation should be used. The most common intuba tion techniques used in patients with Ludwig angina are 
fiberoptic intubation, elective tracheostomy, and awake 
blind nasal intubation. Direct laryngoscopy frequently 
fails because of posterior displacement of the tongue. 
In cases of severe airway compromise, awake fiberoptic 
intubation was attempted. Some researchers have pro posed surgical tracheostomy under nerve block as an 
option for patients who cannot be intubated.
Ultrasound can be beneficial, especially in patients 
who cannot lie supine. Because of the risk of rapid airway 
impairment, immediate consultation may be beneficial 
if anesthesia and otolaryngology are accessible. Flexible 
intubation endoscopy with surgical airway preparation is 
the primary line of airway intervention in the emergency 
department. The medical team transferred these patients 
to the intensive care unit for close airway follow-up [4, 8].
Since different studies support the use of steroids for 
Ludwig angina, there are few reports describing the use 
of steroids in the treatment of Ludwig angina. Although 
it is not absolutely obvious whether steroids are impact ful, the cases recorded thus far imply that there may be 
an advantage in their utilization and do not suggest that 
steroids have a harmful effect [9].
According to recent studies, an increasing number of 
patients with Ludwig angina require intensive care unit 
admission for tracheal intubation and mechanical breath ing. However, it is uncertain whether intensive care 
reduces the death rate in patients with Ludwig angina 
with problems or the length of hospital stay (LOS). Patients with severe infections may require repeated inci sions and drainage in the operating room [10, 11].
A systematic review conducted by Pandit et al. revealed 
that compared with other techniques that involve deep 
injections, superficial/intermediate cervical plexus blocks 
are safer. If the two approaches are equally successful, it 
would appear prudent in most circumstances to use the 
technique with a lower rate of adverse side effects [12].
On the basis of the study conducted by Gupta et  al., 
general anesthesia was not required in any of the 15 
cases, and all patients with Ludwig angina were satisfac torily treated with superficial cervical plexus block [13].
Even for a patient with risk of general anesthesia expo sure, such as pregnant mothers, decompression of Lud wig angina in a 28-week-pregnant patient undergoing 
bilateral superficial cervical plexus block was successful 
[14].
Surgeons have stated that superficial cervical plexus 
blocks for tracheostomy provide excellent operating con ditions. This also prevents the need for sedation. How ever, upper airway obstruction is not good, as it may 
exacerbate the obstruction because of loss of tone of air way muscles [15]. Finally, it is suggested that studies with 
large sample sizes and strong levels of evidence be con ducted to conclude the effectiveness of superficial cervi cal plexus block for airway emergency surgeries.
Technical approach to bilateral superficial cervical 
plexus block
Superficial cervical plexus block is a subcutaneous injec tion technique that targets superficial branches of the 
cervical plexus (C1, C2, C3, and C4) and is conducted 
near the midpoint of the posterior border of the SCM 
muscle. Bilateral superficial cervical plexus block is a 
popular regional anesthesia procedure because of its 
simplicity and effectiveness. Ultrasound-guided ana tomical landmarks (blind technique) are typically used to 
perform the procedure. However, the landmark-guided 
approach is simple to use, although it is difficult to estab lish the position of the needle, and the procedure used 
10  ml of 0.25% bupivacaine for each side of the block 
with a 4 cm 24-gauge needle. Superficial cervical plexus 
blocks can also serve as adjuvant blocks for shoulder, cla vicular, breast, and upper chest wall procedures, specifi cally targeting the supraclavicular branches [7, 8] (Fig. 3).
Superficial cervical plexus block for airway surgery 
and its outcome
When treating patients who have challenging airways 
and require dental abscess drainage, it is advisable to 
administer a superficial cervical plexus block. Addition ally, an auriculotemporal nerve block may be necessary. 
It can provide substantial pain relief, enhance tolerance

to tracheostomy tubes, and maintain stable hemodynam ics [15, 16]. The greatly decreased analgesic consumption 
and low pain score, as well as the significantly improved 
patient satisfaction, show that superficial cervical plexus 
block provides effective pain management for patients 
undergoing carotid endarterectomy and thyroid surgery 
[17, 18].
Castresana et  al. reported that combining deep and 
superficial cervical plexus block can affect diaphragmatic 
motion in 61% of patients. Notably, there seems to be no 
probability that conventional superficial cervical plexus 
blocks the phrenic nerve [19].
Conclusion
To determine the effectiveness of superficial cervical 
plexus blocks for tracheostomy and other airway emer gency surgeries, additional studies need to be conducted. 
However, the management of the airway in patients 
with Ludwig angina is challenging. Clinicians must take 
precautions and make sharp decisions on the basis of a 
variety of circumstances, including the availability of 
equipment at medical facilities, such as fiberoptic intuba tion equipment; the anesthetist’s level of experience, such 
as performing BSCPB and good mask ventilation; and the 
patient’s medical status at the time of presentation. This 
is because Ludwig angina, which is a serious infection, 
can quickly obstruct the airway and lead to further com plications. To achieve the best patient outcomes, a wellequipped operating room and an experienced anesthetist 
with a better management strategy are needed. Addition ally, performing superficial cervical plexus block is better 
for patients with Ludwig angina for tracheostomy tube 
insertion without compromising the airway.Abbreviations
